datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_massSpec_Lasonder_Schizont_Phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Phosphoproteomic analysis of Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 schizont stage
datasetPresenter.description:
Schizont stage Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 phosphoproteome
P. falciparum 3D7 infected erythrocytes were harvested when >90% of parasites were at the multinucleated schizont stage. Protein samples were prepared using two methods: Gel-electrophoresis and Gel-Free Filter Assisted Sample Preparation (FASP). Samples were analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Peptides were identified by searching the mass spectrometry data with Mascot against a combined database of P. falciparum and human proteins and were validated with the target−decoy methods of the MaxQuant software and peptides were discovered using Mascot and MaxQuant.

The corresponding P. falciparum 3D7 schizont stage phosphoproteome can be accessed on PlasmoDB.

datasetPresenter.name: pchachabaudi_Mosquito_And_Blood_Transmitted_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Trophozoite transcriptomes after mosquito transmission or direct injection into mice
datasetPresenter.summary: Illumina mRNA sequencing of P. chabaudi chabaudi AS trophozoites isolated from mice that were infected with serial blood passaged parasites via mosquito bite or direct injection of parasitized erythrocytes.
datasetPresenter.description:
Trophozoite transcriptomes following mosquito transmission or direct injection into mice.
P. chabaudi chabaudi AS trophozoites were isolated from mice that were infected by mosquito bite or direct injection with serial blood passaged parasites. Transcriptomes were assayed by Illumina mRNA sequencing.

Protocol:
C57BL/6 mice were injected with 1 x 105 serial blood passaged parasites or infected through mosquito bite. Parasites were isolated after six cycles of the blood-stage infection, and at the late trophozoite stage of development. Poly A+ mRNA was purified from total parasite RNA using oligo dT dyna bead selection and libraries were created using a modified RNA-seq protocol, where RNA was fragmented using Covaris AFA sonication instead of metal ions. Samples were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq 2000.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Cultured_Sporozoites_Transcriptome_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Mosquito or cultured sporozoites and blood stage transcriptome (NF54)
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomes of Plasmodium falciparum NF54 developmental stages: sporozoites from mosquito saliva, sporozoites from axenic culture and asexual blood stage.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptome expression from Plasmodium falciparum NF54 developmental stages:
  • Sporozoites from mosquito salivaly glands.
  • Sporozoites grown axenically for 3 days.
  • Asexual blood stages.

Illumina RNA-seq reads from each of three developmental stages (2 replicates per sample) were mapped to the reference Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 genome.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Bartfai_time_series_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: RNA sequencing analysis of 8 time points during the P. falciparum 3D7 intraerythrocytic cycle.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptome of the P. falciparum 3D7 intraerythrocytic cycle assayed by RNA sequencing.

Tightly synchronized Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 parasites expressing (primarily) a single var gene (var2csa) were harvested at 8 time-points during intra-erythrocytic development (5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40 hours post-invasion). Total RNA was isolated using RNeasy Mini Colllumns and directional RNA-seq was performed on PolyA+ RNA. Libraries were amplified for 13 cycles using a Plasmodium optimized protocol for KAPA polymerase-mediated PCR amplification and samples were sequenced 100bases single-end on an Illumina HiSeq2000.

This dataset forms a pair with the "P. falciparum 3D7 MNase-Seq Nucleosome Occupancy (Barfai et al)" dataset, which was collected from the exact same batch of synchronized parasites.

The collected parasites correspond to the following eight time-windows post-invasion:
40-5 hours
2-10 hours
7-15 hours
12-20 hours
17-25 hours
22-30 hours
27-35 hours
32-40 hours

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_SNPChip_SNP_Chip_Artesunate_Resistance_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genotype calls for ~8,000 SNPs generated from Affymetrix SNP array analysis on samples collected during clinical trials of artesunate and ACTs in Southeast Asia
datasetPresenter.description:
Genotype calls for ~8,000 SNPs generated from Affymetric SNP array analysis on samples collected during clinical trials of artesunate and ACTs in Southeast Asia

ARC3 Clinical Trials
Clinical trials of artesunate efficacy were conducted at two sites in western Cambodia (Pailin and Tasanh), and one site each in northwestern Thailand (Wang Pha) and Bangladesh (Bandarban) following protocols approved by the Research Ethics Review Committee of the World Health Organization, as well as local Institutional Review Boards at each study site. Details of each trial are shown in Table S1 of the publication.

Parasite Genotyping
DNA was extracted from leukocyte-depleted blood and underwent whole-genome amplification (WGA) and genotyped at 8,079 SNPs using a molecular inversion probe Affymetrix P. falciparum SNP array. The assay was performed following the Affymetrix GeneChip Scanner 3000 User Guide without modification, except for alterations made to the first PCR thermal cycling parameters.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Chabbert_TSS_GFF_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: TSS regions for P.falciparum 3D7.
datasetPresenter.description:
Genome-wide transcription start sites mapping based on high-throughput sequencing of 5' cap-selected mRNA molecules isolated from 6 time points during P. falciparum 3D7 intra-erythrocytic asexual cycle.
The data are derived frim biological replicates collected at 8-hour intervals throughout the IDC of P. falciparum 3D7. Because transcription initiation events across broad genomic regions, these initiation events were 'grouped' into clusters in a systematic manner by adapting filtering methods originally developed for image processing. The filtering approach is based on varying one parameter until the selection of the final, 'most adequate' parameter value, which is determined automatically for each gene. For each explored parameter value, we generated a filtered signal and the corresponding annotation. Currently this data is loaded as tracks in the genome browser. View this data in the genome browser.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayExpression_Llinas_RT_Transcription_Decay_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Biosynthetic pyrimidine labeling was used for the calculation of real-time, whole-genome analysis of transcription and stability throughout asexual development of P. falciparum 3D7 strain.
datasetPresenter.description: A 48-hour timecourse experiment of highly synchronized P. falciparum 3D7 expressing FCU-GFP in which individual hourly time points were exposed to 40um 4-thiouracil for 10min immediately followed by total RNA extraction. Total RNA from each timepoint was biotinylated via a thiol-group on any transcript that incorporated a thiol-modified dUTP during this time. Biotinylated transcripts were separated from total RNA by Streptavidin magnetic beads resulting in the labeled mRNA sample (red). Unbound mRNA (unlabeled, blue) comprises the remainder of mRNA pool. Prior to biotinylation, total RNA from each sample was set aside and utilized to determine the global total mRNA abundance. For each hourly time point, the three samples (labeled, unlabeled, and total) were analyzed using whole genome Agilent DNA microarrays (Kafsack et al., 2012) resulting in a total of 144 individual microarrays. The resulting intensity values for each gene were utilized to computationally determine the relative contribution of transcription (labeled) and stability/decay (unlabeled) to the total mRNA abundance measured.

datasetPresenter.name: pberANKA_microarrayPlatform_WatersDOZIOligos_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Probe sequences from the P. berghei 60-mer oligos. Zoom to 20K or less to see the probe glyphs.
datasetPresenter.description: Sixty-mer oligonucleotides for the 5283 predicted P. berghei transcripts were designed using the Oligo Picky software. Oligonucleotide sequences were designed to be complementary to regions within 1 kb from the 3 prime UTR of transcripts and had a minimal sequence identity overlap with non-target transcript sequences. Microarrays were constructed through in situ synthesis of oligonucleotides on glass slides by Agilent Technologies (www.agilent.com).Zoom to 20K or less to see the probe glyphs.

datasetPresenter.name: pberANKA_microarrayPlatform_WatersGSSOligos_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Genome Survey Sequence Array probe sequences
datasetPresenter.summary: Probe sequences from the P. berghei Genome Survey Sequence DNA microarray. Zoom to 20K or less to see the probe glyphs.
datasetPresenter.description:
Probe sequences from the P. berghei Genome Survey Sequence DNA microarray.
The 6.3 K P. berghei DNA microarray was generated from a P. berghei genomic DNA library, supplied by J. Dame and J. M. Carlton (University of Florida). Briefly, genomic DNA obtained from the blood stages of clone cyclc15 of P. berghei ANKA was digested with mung bean nuclease. Mung bean nuclease digestion generates DNA fragments that contain intact genes rather than intergenic regions, thereby reducing the complexity of the library. The library consists of 6354 clones size selected in the range 500-2000 bp, and each clone has been sequenced at the 5’ end to generate a genome survey sequence (GSS).

For spotting on the glass slide, a total of 25 known P. berghei genes and ten mouse, mosquito and bacterial genes were amplified from genomic or plasmid DNA and used as controls on the microarray. The GSS library and the control genes were spotted on aminosilane-coated glass slides, using the Omnigrid microarray spotter (GeneMachines).

datasetPresenter.description:
The GeneChip Plasmodium/Anopheles Genome Array includes probe sets to over 4,300 Plasmodium falciparum transcripts and approximately 14,900 Anopheles gambiae transcripts. The Plasmodium/Anopheles Genome Array was developed in collaboration with the Malaria Research Institute at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.

P. falciparum sequence information for this array was collected primarily from PlasmoDB (version 4.1, June 2003) and augmented with sequence information from GenBank and dbEST. Sequence information for A. gambiae was drawn primarily from Ensembl (Build 2, 2003) and augmented with sequence information from GenBank and dbEST.

Probe sequences for the Scripps Malaria GeneChip, a custom microarray platform for P. falciparum.
The design of this novel high-density oligonucleotide array was based on the P. falciparum sequence data released in July 2001. The custom array contains probes to at least 5159 P. falciparum genes, and was synthesized using photosensitive oligonucleotide chemistry and photolithography by Affymetrix (Santa Clara, CA).

EuPathDB downloaded the probe sequences from Gene Expression Omnibus record GPL1892.

datasetPresenter.description: ArrayExpress (A-MEXP-75). The 70-mer oligonucleotides microarray consisted of 6850 probes. From there, 6542 probes (Malaria Genome Oligo Set Version 1.0) were designed and synthesized by Qiagen Operon and 14 probes were obtained from the SpotReport Alien oligo array validation system (Stratagene, CA, USA). The rest of the oligos were selected using ArrayDesigner Version 1 (Premier Biosoft International, CA, USA). Oligonucleotides were dissolved in 1:3 of DMSO:dH2O at a final concentration of 40 microM in preparation for spotting on CMT-UltraGaps slides. Microarraying was done by Genetix Qarray. Each probe was printed in quadruplicate on the slides.

datasetPresenter.summary: Probe sequences from the Affymetrix P. vivax whole genome tiling array PvivaxLi520507 (Westenberger). Zoom to 20K or less to see the probe glyphs.
datasetPresenter.description: We designed a Affymetrix custom P. vivax whole-genome tiling microarray with 4.2 million 25-bp probes covering both strands at six base pair spacing, based on the genome assembly of 2809 contigs (PlasmoDB Ver. 5.4). This microarray includes 1.7 and 2.3 million probes uniquely mapped to coding regions and non-coding regions, respectively. Altogether 5419 P. vivax genes are represented on the array, 4676 of which have P. falciparum orthologs. This array will be made available for purchase from Affymetrix, part number PvivaxLi520507.

datasetPresenter.name: pyoeyoelii17X_microarrayPlatform_Affy-scrMalaria_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Probe sequences from the P. yoelii SCR Malaria oligos. Zoom to 20K or less to see the probe glyphs.
datasetPresenter.description: The spotted microarray contained 7,080 65-mer oligonucleotides (probes). Each probe was spotted twice on the array. The array has been developed and previously evaluated with hybridizations of total RNA extracted from blood stages. Probe sequences were blasted against annotated P. yoelii genes downloaded from PlasmoDB (version 5.2). In total, 6,451 probes were specifically mapped to 6,428 annotated P. yoelii genes with a perfect match.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_chipChipPlatform_GPL8808-wg_cgh_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Probe sequences Plasmodium falciparum 385K tiling array (GPL8808). Zoom to 20K or less to see the probe glyphs.
datasetPresenter.description: DESIGN_ID DESIGN_NAME DESCRIPTION 1992 2005-05-10_Plasmodium_3D7_WG_CGH Plasmodium genome (3D7) tiled at 45 bp spacing. Probes selected at 4 bp primary interval with a 4 bp secondary interval. 10 probes selected at each primary interval and then uniqueness, frequency and basic rule scoring determined. Instead of normal Tm tiling, probes were allowed to grow as long as possible given the 148 synthesis cycle cutoff. Rank selection done for each primary interval 'cluster'. The 478402 probes selected by the rank selection were then filtered further: rules >= -300; frequency <= 25; tm: 60-80. This left 385585 probes for the design. Also added 2883 random tm70 probes with the following parameters: tm 70; 148 cycles; min length: 45; max length: 85; gc: 23%.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Caro_ribosome_profiling_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Ribosome and steady state mRNA sequencing of asexual cell cycle stages
datasetPresenter.summary: Ribosome profiling and steady state mRNA sequencing through five stages of the P. falciparum blood phase developmental cycle. RNA from W2 strain asexual stages were aligned to P. falciparum 3D7.
datasetPresenter.description:
RNA sequencing of total (steady state) and polysome-associated mRNA during 5 stages of the P. falciparum blood phase asexual life cycle stages. RNA from W2 strain asexual stages were aligned to P. falciparum 3D7.

Five stages representative of the 48-hr intraerythrocytic developmental cycle of P. falciparum W2 were harvested for both total steady state mRNA and polysome isolation; ring, early trophozoite, late trophozoite, schizont stages, and purified merozoites. mRNA samples were fragmented to ~30 nt for consistency with the nuclease digested ribosome protected mRNA. RNA fragments, corresponding to ribosome footprints and fragmented mRNA, were processed into strand-specific libraries for deep sequencing with Illumina HiSeq 2000. PlasmoDB aligned the reads to the P. falciparum 3D7 reference genome.

Sample names on PlasmoDB:
Ring (R) = ring 11h
early trophozoite (ET) = troph 21h
late trophozoite (LT) = troph 31h
schizont (S) = schiz 45h
merozoite (M) = merozoite (purified from schizont stages)

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayExpression_Pelle_sexual_commitment_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Sexually vs asexually committed schizont transcriptional profiles
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptional profile during schizont sexual committment to gametocytes: Gene expression (microarray) of sexually vs asexually committed schizonts in the P2G12 gametocyte-producing derivative of P. falciparum 3D7.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptional profiles of asexually vs sexually committed schizonts

Cultures enriched in sexually committed schizonts were produced by stressing a highly synchronous trophozoite population from the transgenic parasite line 164/TdTom that expresses a red fluorescent protein reporter under a gametocyte-specific promoter. Fluorescent (sexually committed) and non-fluorescent (asexually committed) mature schizonts were isolated by Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorting (FACS). Gating of fluorescent versus non-fluorescent schizonts was based on nuclear content using Vybrant Violet dye and TdTom fluorescence, with the wild-type parasite as a negative control. RNA was prepared from each culture and analyzed by microarray (GEO record GPL8604) to produce a transcriptional profile during sexual committment.

Samples

1. asexually committed schizonts
2. sexually committed schizonts

Note that the microarray analysis method used by EuPathDB resources might differ from those used by the authors in the original publication. This may cause some differences in overall results but the general trend should be the same.

link.text: GEO record for the microarray platform used in this study

templateInjector.prop: Bars represent asexually committed (non-fluorescent) and sexually committed (fluorescent)

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayAntibody__ICEMR_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: International Centers of Excellence for Malaria Research
datasetPresenter.summary: An NIH program establishing a network of independent research centers in malaria-endemic settings.
datasetPresenter.description:
The International Centers of Excellence for Malaria Research (ICEMR) program, created in July 2010, established a global network of independent research centers in malaria-endemic settings to provide knowledge, tools, and evidence-based strategies to support researchers working in a variety of settings, especially within governments and healthcare institutions.

Research activities are being conducted in the following regions, comprising more than 20 countries:

Malaria Transmission and the Impact of Control Efforts in Southern Africa
Principal Investigator: Peter Agre, M.D.
Lead Institution: Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore

Center for the Study of Complex Malaria in India
Principal Investigator: Jane Carlton, Ph. D.
Lead Institution: New York University School of Medicine, New York City

Southeast Asia Malaria Research Center
Principal Investigator: Liwang Cui, Ph.D.
Lead Institution: Pennsylvania State University, University Park

Program for Resistance, Immunology, Surveillance & Modeling of Malaria in Uganda
Principal Investigator: Matthew Dorsey, M.D.
Lead Institution: University of California, San Francisco

Latin American Center for Malaria Research and Control
Principal Investigator: Socrates Herrera-Valencia, M.D.
Lead Institution: Caucaseo Scientific Research Center, Cali, Colombia

Research to Control and Eliminate Malaria in SE Asia and SW Pacific
Principal Investigator: James Kazura, M.D.
Lead Institution: Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland

Population-based Approach to Malaria Research and Control in West Africa
Principal Investigator: Donald Krogstad, M.D.
Lead Institution: Tulane University, New Orleans

Malaria Evolution in South Asia
Principal Investigator: Pradipsinh Rathod, Ph. D.
Lead Institution: University of Washington, Seattle

Determinants of Malaria Disease in Malawi
Principal Investigator: Terrie Taylor, D.O.
Lead Institution: Michigan State University, East Lansing

Peruvian/Brazilian Amazon Center of Excellence in Malaria
Principal Investigator: Joseph Vinetz, M.D.
Lead Institution: University of California, San Diego

Each Center aims to
- Design and conduct multidisciplinary research on the epidemiology, transmission, and pathogenesis of malaria in its specific region
- Design and conduct special projects to capitalize on new opportunities and emerging public health needs
- Develop and conduct training/career development programs for researchers in its region

link.text: Am J Trop Med Hyg 2015 ICEMR issue
ICEMR program overview on NIAID website

datasetPresenter.name: pmalUG01_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Sequence for Plasmodium malariae strain UG01
datasetPresenter.description:
A de novo genome assembly of P. malariae was produced using long-read Pacific Biosciences sequencing. The isolate was sourced from a patient attending the Royal Darwin Hospital, Darwin, Australia, who had recently returned from Uganda. The patient blood sample was subject to leukodepletion within 6 hours of collection using a commercial Plasmodipur filter (EuroProxima, The Netherlands). We were able to assemble large sections of the subtelomeric regions, resulting in a genome size of approximately 33.6 Mb consisting of less than 70 contigs.

This work was funded by the Medical Research Council and the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. The DNA was provided by Sarah Auburn and Ric Price (Menzies School of Health Research). The assembly was performed by Gavin G. Rutledge.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: This genome is actively curated at GeneDB. User comments added to this gene will be reviewed and incorporated into the official annotation if appropriate.

datasetPresenter.name: povaGH01_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Sequence for Plasmodium ovale curtisi GH01
datasetPresenter.description:
A de novo genome assembly of P. ovale curtisi was produced using 100bp paired-end Illumina sequencing on a HiSeq 2000 version 3. The isolate was sourced from a patient attending the Navrongo War Memorial hospital, Ghana. The patient blood sample was subject to leukodepletion using CF11 cellulose powder columns. We were able to assemble large sections of the subtelomeric regions, resulting in a genome size of approximately 33.5 Mb consisting of less than 700 contigs.

This work was funded by the Medical Research Council and the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. The DNA was provided by Lucas Amenga-Etego (Navrongo Health Research Centre). The assembly was performed by Gavin G. Rutledge.
datasetPresenter.releasePolicy: This genome is actively curated at GeneDB. User comments added to this gene will be reviewed and incorporated into the official annotation if appropriate.
datasetPresenter.history: re-annotated, mitochondrial genome and annotation removed, Strain name changed from curtisiGH01 to GH01, species name changed from Plasmodium ovale to Plasmodium ovale curtisi

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_massSpec_Lasonder_Bartfai_Gametocytes_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomics data for the male, female and mixed P. falciparum gametocytes
datasetPresenter.description:
A Plamodium falciparum NF54 parasite line was generated where GFP under control of the male-specific dynein (PF3D7_1023100) promoter was integrated into the silent p52 locus (PF3D7_0404500), and mCherry under control of the female-specific p47 promoter (PF3D7_1346800) was expressed from a centromere-containing plasmid. Mature gametocytes (stage IV/V) were FACS-sorted into two male (GFP+; GFP+/mCherry+) and a female (mCherry+) population, which were used for proteomics analysis.

Proteomics:
Purified male and female gametocytes from three/four independent parasite cultures were pooled to produce a single male and female gametocyte sample. Peptide identification experiments were performed by LC-MS/MS. Mass spectrometry data was analysed with the Andromeda search engine integrated in the proteomics software suite MaxQuant version 1.3.05.

Associated Data Set:
This Proteomics data set has a corresponding transcriptomics data set called Female and Male Gametocyte Transcriptomes.

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_HTS_SNP_Field_Isolates_QuerySRA_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - Field and monkey adapted Isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: Whole genome sequencing of P. vivax isolates obtained from Malagasy and Cambodian patients, and of the Belem, Chesson and Sal I strains.
datasetPresenter.description: Whole genome sequencing of P. vivax isolates obtained from Malagasy and Cambodian patients, and of the monkey-adapted Belem, Chesson and Sal I strains. Blood samples from were obtained from three Malagasy (M08, M15 and M19) and three Cambodian patients (C08, C15 and C127). DNA was also extracted from the monkey-adapted Belem, Chesson and Sal I strains of P. vivax. An average 70–400 X coverage of each genome, resulting in more than 93% of the Sal I reference sequence covered by 20 reads or more.

datasetPresenter.description: Selective whole-genome amplification was used to amplify the genome of Plasmodium reichenowi SY57. Libraries were sequenced using the Illumina MiSeq and SNPs against the Plasmodium reichenowi CDC reference genome were determined.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Lasonder_Bartfai_Gametocytes_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Directional RNA-seq data from P. falciparum NF54 for female and male gameocyte samples.
datasetPresenter.description:
Samples:
A Plamodium falciparum NF54 parasite line was generated where GFP under control of the male-specific dynein (PF3D7_1023100) promoter was integrated into the silent p52 locus (PF3D7_0404500), and mCherry under control of the female-specific p47 promoter (PF3D7_1346800) was expressed from a centromere-containing plasmid. Mature gametocytes (stage IV/V) were FACS-sorted into two male (GFP+; GFP+/mCherry+) and a female (mCherry+) population, which were used for strand-specific RNA-seq.

Transcriptomics:

Associated Data Set:
This transcriptomics data set has a corresponding proteomics data set called Female and Male Gametocyte Proteomes.

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_intraerythrocyticTimeSeries_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcription profile of the P. vivax intraerythrocytic cycle
datasetPresenter.description:
Plasmodium vivax transcriptome of the Intraerythrocytic developmental cycle of two clinical isolates (SMRU1 and SMRU2) collected from Northwesterm Thailand in high resolution by Illumina HiSeq platform. Overall, 15 parasite samples (7 for SMRU1 and 8 from SMRU2 isolates) were collected from ex vivo cultures. The samples corresponded to the following time points:
SMRU1: 6 hr, 18 hr, 24 hr, 30 hr, 36 hr, 42 hr and 48 hr.
SMRU2: 6 hr, 12 hr, 18 hr, 24 hr, 30 hr, 36 hr, 42 hr and 48 hr

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_massSpec_Sporozoite_surface_proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteome of P. falciparum NF54 salivary gland sporozoite surface proteins isolated by affinity enrichment of surface-exposed proteins labeled with a biotin tag.
datasetPresenter.description:
Surface proteome of salivary gland sporozoites.
P. falciparum NF54 sporozoites were obtained by dissection of salivary glands from infected mosquitoes and then purified twice on an Accudenz gradient. Live parasites were treated with a cell-impermeable, amine-reactive tag that attached a biotin moiety to surface-exposed lysine residues and N-termini. Subsequently, parasites were lysed and biotin-labeled proteins were purified using streptavidin affixed to magnetic beads. The affinity-purified proteins were eluted and fractionated by SDS-PAGE. Peptides resulting from in-gel digestion with trypsin were analyzed by nanoLC-MS/MS employing an LTQ Velos Pro-Orbitrap Elite. Mass spectrometry data were analyzed with the Trans-Proteomic Pipeline.

Samples:
untreated sporozoites (6 replicates)
heparin-treated sporozoites (3 replicates)
BSA-treated sporozoites (3 replicates)

datasetPresenter.name: pyoeyoelii17X_massSpec_Sporozoite_Surface_Proteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Salivary gland sporozoite total and surface proteome (17XNL)
datasetPresenter.summary: P yoelii 17XNL sporozoite total and surface proteomes (2013) as well as PlasmoSEP surface proteomes (2016)
datasetPresenter.description:
Plasmodium yoelii 17XNL total and surface proteome of salivary gland sporozoites.
Total and surface proteins:
Plasmodium yoelii 17XNL sporozoites were micro-disected from mosquito salivary glands and purified to remove mosquito debris. Sporozoite proteins were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS as whole cell lysates or as purified surface biotinylated proteins. Spectra were searched (XITandem, SEQUEST) against a database comprising P. falciparum, P. yoelii, A. gambia, common protein contaminants and decoys. (PMID 23325771)

PlasmoSEP sporozoite surface proteins:
Plasmodium yoelii 17XNL strain sporozoites were micro-dissected from mosquito salivary glands and purified twice by Accudenz to remove mosquito debris. Sporozoite proteins were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS as as purified surface biotinylated proteins (surface-exposed proteome) and were compared to a matched no biotinylated crosslinker control to remove background. Spectra were searched (XITandem, Comet) against a database comprising P. yoelii, An. stephensi, common protein contaminants, and decoys. (PMID 27714937)

Samples:
sg-sporozoite: total sporozoite proteome (PMID 23325771)
surface proteins: salivary gland sporozoite surface proteome (PMID 23325771)
sporozoite surface - Rep 1: PlasmoSEP derived surface proteome replicate 1 (PMID 27714937)
sporozoite surface - Rep 2: PlasmoSEP derived surface proteome replicate 2 (PMID 27714937)
datasetPresenter.history: Data added: PlasmoSEP samples from PMID 27714937

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_massSpec_sporozoite_proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Salivary gland sporozoite total and surface proteome (VK210, VK247)
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteins identified from P. vivax salivary gland sporozoites, including putatively surface-exposed proteins identified by surface labeling with a membrane-impermeable biotin tag.
datasetPresenter.description: Total and surface-exposed proteins: Proteins present in P. vivax salivary gland sporozoites were identified by mass spectrometry-based proteomics. Sporozoites were obtained from mosquitoes fed with infected blood obtained from patients who presented at health centers in Thailand. Parasites were typed by PCR as bearing either the VK210 or the VK247 haplotype of circumsporozoite protein (CSP). Whole proteome surveys were performed for one replicate each of VK210 and VK247 sporozoites. Additionally, putatively surface-exposed proteins were identified for one replicate each of VK210 and VK247 sporozoites by labeling with a membrane-impermeable, amine-reactive biotin tag. (Note that all proteins identified by the surface labeling experiments have been listed here, but not all are presumed to be truly surface-exposed on sporozoites. See the associated manuscript for further details on which proteins were considered high-confidence putative surface proteins.)

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_phenotype_pB_mutagenesis_MIS_MFS_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: P. falciparum NF54 mutants were generated via random piggyBac transposon mutagenesis. Mutants are genetically identical except for a single randomly inserted transposon at TTAA tetranucleotide sites.
datasetPresenter.description:
P. falciparum NF54 mutants were generated via random piggyBac transposon mutagenesis. Mutants are genetically identical except for a single randomly inserted transposon at TTAA tetranucleotide sites.

This study exploits the AT-richness of the P. falciparum genome, which provides numerous piggyBac transposon insertion targets within both gene coding and noncoding flanking sequences, to generate more than 38,000 P. falciparum mutants. At this level of mutagenesis, essential genes are distinguished as nonmutable and dispensable genes as mutable. Subsequently, 2680 genes were identified as essential for in vitro asexual blood-stage growth.

Mutagenesis index scores (MISs) and mutagenesis fitness scores (MFSs) were calculated in order to functionally define the relative fitness cost of disruption for 5399 genes. A competitive growth phenotype screen confirmed that MIS and MFS were predictive of the fitness cost for in vitro asexual growth.

For details please see the publication Zhang et al. Science Vol. 360, Issue 6388, eaap7847.

datasetPresenter.name: pberANKA_phenotype_Bushnell_functional_profiling_RSRC
datasetPresenter.shortAttribution: Bushell, Gomes and Sanderson et al.
datasetPresenter.summary: PlasmoGEM knockout vectors were used to measure growth rate phenotypes in mice for 2,578 P. berghei genes, representing more than half of its protein-coding genome.
datasetPresenter.description: Barcoded PlasmoGEM knockout vectors were used to generate 2,578 P. berghei mutant parasites that were pooled (~100 per pool) to measure growth rate phenotypes in mice. Relative growth rate (RGR) for each mutant was determined by counting sequenced barcodes in daily blood samples. Changes in barcode abundance were normalized against seven control vectors each pool. Some mutants increased over time, while others dropped out on different days depending on their competitive fitness and their initial abundance. Data was aggregated from at least three replicate transfections into a single best estimate of RGR and calculated a 95% confidence interval (CI) for each mutant.

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_Bhatia_Hynozoite_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: P. vivax hypnozoite RNAseq
datasetPresenter.description: RNAseq was performed on hypnozoite enriched and control (mixed) cultures from two clinical Thai Plasmodium vivax isolates grown in vitro in micropatterned primary human hepatocyte co-cultures. Parasite cDNA was enriched by hybrid selection prior to sequencing.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Scherf_Ring_Oocyst_Sporozoite_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Transcriptomes of oocyst, ring and sporozoite stages in P. falciparum determined by RNA sequence.
datasetPresenter.description:
Transcriptomes of oocyst, ring and sporozoite stages in P. falciparum.
Total RNA from sporozoites, oocysts, or asexual ring stage parasites was extracted using the miRNeasy Mini Kit (QIAGEN) according to the manufacturer’s instructions, including on-column DNase digestion. Poly(A)-enriched total RNA was subjected to strand-specific RNA-seq library preparation using the TruSeq Stranded mRNA Library Prep Kit (Illumina). The libraries were multiplexed and subjected to 150-bp single end sequencing on an Illumina NextSeq 500. A minimum of two biological replicates was analyzed for each parasite stage

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_Zanghi_Sporo_Ring_chipSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Epigenome of sporozoites (HP-1, H3K9me3, H3K9ac) and rings (HP-1, H3K9me3).
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome-wide distribution of HP-1 and H3K9me3 in P. falciparum rings and sporozoites, as well as H3K9ac in sporozoites.
datasetPresenter.description: The genome-wide distribution of heterochromatin in P. falciparum sporozoite and ring stages was determined using ChIP Seq with highly specific antibodies against PfHP1, the transcriptionally repressive histone H3 modification lysine 9 trimethylation (H3K9me3). Active transcription was analyzed in sporozoites using ChIP Seq with H3K9ac.

The distribution in the intraerythrocytic cycle was determined with Pf3D7 strain ring, and trophozoite samples as well as Pf2004 gametocyte II/III and IV/V stages.

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_HTS_SNP_Sanger_Natural_Genome_Variation_QuerySRA_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned genomic sequence reads - strain P01
datasetPresenter.summary: Field isolates of Plasmodium vivax are being sequenced to provide contributing investigators with genetic data to support locally-driven studies, while also contributing to the development of a global map of P. vivax genome variation. This global dataset will provide a resource for genome-wide association studies and other genomic studies aimed at identifying genetic loci responsible for such phenotypes as antimalarial drug resistance.
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequencing of clinical samples of Plasmodium vivax. This data is part of a pre-publication release. For information on the proper use of pre-publication data shared by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute (including details of any publication moratoria), please see http://www.sanger.ac.uk/datasharing/

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_HTS_SNP_Otto_GeoDispersedIsolates_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Illumina whole genome sequencing of P falciparum isolates and lab strains. Data were aligned to the Pf3D7 reference genome was used to determine SNPs.
datasetPresenter.description:
Illumina whole genome sequencing of P falciparum isolates and lab strains.

All cultured parasite lines were maintained under standard conditions. 3D7 was from the same stock as the one used for the genome project published in 2002. IT, Dd2, HB3, GB4, 7G8 are routinely used laboratory isolates. Clones of KH01 and KH02, previously named KH1-01 and KH2-0, were also used. Isolate GA01 from Gabon refers to the MOA D2 Clone that was generated by limiting dilution from the MOA bulk cultures. The isolates from Sudan (SD01), Togo (TG01) and Congo (CD01) were culture-adapted from diagnostic specimens submitted for routine malaria diagnosis to the laboratory of the outpatient clinic of the Institute of Tropical Medicine in Tübingen, Germany. The clinical samples ML01 from Nioro du Sahel, Mali (Lat 15.183, Long -9.550), and GN01 from Faranah, Guinea (Lat 10.040, Long -10.743) were directly obtained from patients presenting at local health facilities. The Senegalese sample SenT021.09 was collected in Thies, Senegal in 2009. The isolate PfKE01, also known as 9106, based on the naming system adopted at KEMR-Wellcome Trust laboratories for clinical P. falciparum isolates, was used in previous studies.

For each sample, we obtained between 6 – 20 ug of high molecular weight DNA and used for Illumina sequencing. We used the PCR-free method to generate the libraries, using 0.5 ug of DNA for each. Libraries were sequenced using the MiSeq Illumina platform with 250 bp paired end reads and a fragment length of 500 bp. In general, 3–4 samples were indexed and pooled per run.

Samples:
Pf3D7
Guinea - GN01
Congo - CD01
Dd2 - Dd2
Kenya - KE01
Cambodia - KH01
7G8 - 7G8
Gabon - GA01
GB4 - GB4
Cambodia - KH02
IT - IT
Sudan - SD01
Togo - TG01
HB3 - HB3
Senegal - SN01
Mali - ML01

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_HTS_SNP_Gilabert_P_vivax-like_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Whole genome sequencing of P. vivax-like isolates
datasetPresenter.summary: A total of 11 P. vivax-like samples were obtained from infected chimpanzee blood samples and an infected mosquito collected in Gabon.
datasetPresenter.description: Eleven P. vivax-like genotypes were obtained from 2 different kinds of samples: 10 infected chimpanzee blood samples collected during successive routine sanitary controls of chimpanzees living in the Park of La Lékédi (a sanctuary in Gabon) and 1 infected Anopheles mosquito (An. moucheti) collected during an entomological survey carried out in the same park. Genome sequence and annotation of a Plasmodium vivax-like isolate obtained from an infected chimpanzee in Gabon.

datasetPresenter.name: pvivP01_HTS_SNP_Hahn_African_Ape_Isolates_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence data of P. vivax strains infecting six chimpanzees
datasetPresenter.description: Leftover blood samples from routine health examinations of chimpanzees cared for at the Sanaga-Yong (SY) Chimpanzee Rescue Center in Cameroon were screened for Plasmodium infection using nested PCR with pan-Plasmodium and P. vivax-specific primers. Two samples, SY56 and SY43, were positive for ape P. vivax, with limiting-dilution PCR detecting one strain in SY56 and up to five variants in SY43, with two strains predominating. We also amplified ape P. vivax from blood samples of two additional SY chimpanzees (SY81 and SY90), from a wild-living western chimpanzee (Sagu) from Côte d’Ivoire (10), and from a western lowland gorilla (Gor3157) sampled in Cameroon.

datasetPresenter.name: pfal3D7_microarrayAntibody_Helb_RecentExposure_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Antibody array of recent exposure to Plasmodium infection
datasetPresenter.summary: This study assessed responses to 856 P. falciparum antigens by protein microarray in 186 Ugandan children, for whom detailed P. falciparum exposure data were available.
datasetPresenter.description: This study probed plasma from participants in two cohort studies in Uganda against a protein microarray containing 856 P. falciparum (Pf) antigens. The primary aim of this analysis was to identify responses to select antigens that were most informative of recent exposure using robust, data-adaptive statistical methods. Each participant’s responses to these selected antigens were used as predictors for two primary outcomes of their recent exposure to Pf: (i) days since last Pf infection and (ii) the incidence of symptomatic malaria in the last year. These individual-level estimates were then aggregated across a population to assess community-level malaria exposure.
